Morrison Tony Morrison is one of those

in 1970 Morrison finally published a

like the
1977 National book critic Circle award

her induction into the Ohio Women's Hall
of Fame in
1982 but it was in 1987 she published
her fifth novel beloved which would
cement Tony Morrison as a truly iconic
American writer beloved was a
GameChanger it not only garnered
Morrison the pulit surprise for fiction
and paved the way for her to become the
first black American to win the Nobel
Peace Prize for literature in 1993 but
it has also become a novel that is all
at once popular influential and hotly
controversial which is why it can be on
the BBC News list of 100 most
influential novels while also regularly
appearing on the American Library
association's top 10 most challenged
books the reason for beloved being so
controversial well it all brings us back
to the horrors of the past including
unflinching depictions of violence
infanticide and slavey in a postmodern
move that would make even Virginia wolf
blush one could argue that those wishes
to ban the novel maybe committing the
same offense as beloved's protagonists
refusing to confront the past in hopes
that doing so will make it go away our
story is said in Cincinnati Ohio in 1873
shortly after the Civil War technically
the war is over technically the enslaved
are free juneth has happened but that
doesn't change the entrenched beliefs
and behavior of a country overnight so
setha finds herself in a sort of
purgatory
existence technically free but not truly
psychologically spiritually free Tony
Morrison writes every day was a test and
a trial nothing could be counted on in a
world where even when you were a
solution you were a problem even worse
what small semblance of freedom and
autonomy she has as a mother and
caretaker for her family is slipping
from her grasp her mother-in-law baby
shs has long since passed away her
husband went missing years ago her two
young Sons Howard and bulgar ran off her
other baby daughter beloved is dead but
not gone so by 1873 that just leaves
setha and her 18-year-old daughter
Denver to fend for themselves at 124 Blu
Stone Road and the Ghost of Seth's baby
girl all the while haunting them for
Seth's pins Morrison rides of the house
on Bluestone Road 124 was spiteful full
of a baby's Venom the women in the house
knew it and so did the children when
Paul D one of the formerly enslaved men
from Seth's former Plantation Sweet Home
arrives he forces the ghost out but then
the ghost reforms into the body of a
young woman who calls herself beloved
beloved begins to torment Paul D pushing
him out of the house and forcing him to
revisit horrible moments from his past
using sexual violence setha eventually
confesses to Paul D that she tried to
kill her children in order to not have
them return to slavery but managed only
to kill her baby daughter beloved was
the only name she could afford to put on
the gravestone thinking that beloved's
return signals her family coming back
together setha begins to give all she is
to beloved until beloved grows bigger
and setha begins to wither away Denver
reaches out to the community of village
women to be rid of beloved to exercise
her bringing their family back into the

new path for herself now as setha
finally Mourns truly for the child she
lost Tony Morris had explains how she

follows she is a spirit on one hand
literally she is what setha thinks she
is her child returned to her from the
dead she is also another kind of dead
which is not spiritual but flesh which
is a Survivor from a true factual
slaveship she speaks the language
anguage a traumatized language of her
own experience which blends beautifully
in her questions and answers her
preoccupations with the desires of
Denver and setha the gap between Africa
and afro America and the gap between the
living and the dead and the gap between
the past and the present does not exist
it's bridge for us by our assuming
responsibility for people no one's ever

those that died in root nobody knows

there is a necessity for remembering the

it can be digested in a manner in which
the memory is not destructive Bel
Lover's return in the novel is about
bringing that past to the surface
because it must be faced it cannot be
stuffed in a box or forgotten for
Morrison horror and Truth are synonymous
that horror is also in the realization
that setha killed her daughter in an
attempt to save her from being
recaptured into slavery a moment
inspired by the real life case of
Margaret Garner Garner was an enslaved
woman who was attempting to escape
slavery with her family while pregnant
mind you Garner was captured in Ohio
under the jurisdiction of the Fugitive
Slave Act where it was discovered that
she had killed her 2-year-old daughter
rather than have the girl be sent back
into slavery She Was preparing to kill
her other children and herself when she
was stopped by a slave catcher posi when
Margaret was brought to trial the
question was if she would be tried as a
person or as property Lucy Stone a
prominent activist at the time took the
stand during the case and said The Faded
faces of the Negro children tell too
plainly to what degradation the female
slave submit rather than give her
daughter to that life she killed it if
in her deep maternal love she felt the
impulse to send her child back to God to
save it from coming woe who shall say
she had no right not to do
so Margaret was sent back to slavery and
would eventually die within the
institution with setha Morrison gives
the historical figure space to mourn in
the freedom she made sacrifices for
Barbara T Christian professor of
African-American studies at the
University of California Berkeley said
of the importance of the work beloved
interrogates our assumptions about

that stands on the very Foundation of

this past to confront it and hopefully
